title: 112_hr3012
content: The Act titled "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" imposes a numerical limitation on visas from any single foreign state. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust visa limitations for immigrants from single foreign states under the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011". The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust visa limitations for immigrants from single foreign states under the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011." Special rules are established for countries at the visa ceiling, ensuring equal allocation of visa numbers among different categories. Additionally, a country-specific offset is made under the Chinese Student Protection Act of 1992. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust visa limitations for immigrants from single foreign states under the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011." The Protection Act of 1992 is also amended to change subsections and transition rules for employment-based immigrants, with specific visa allotments for natives of certain states. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust visa limitations for immigrants from single foreign states under the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011." For fiscal years 2013 and 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest numbers of immigrant visas. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust visa limitations for immigrants from single foreign states under the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011." Visa allotments are restricted to 25 percent for a single foreign state and 2 percent for a dependent area, with unreserved visas subject to specific limitations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust visa limitations for immigrants from single foreign states under the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011." Unreserved visas for fiscal years 2012-2014 are limited to 85% for natives of any single foreign state, with special rules to prevent unused visas and determine chargeability. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 29, 2011. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
